results.headline: ‘Time to Leave’ Shows Loneliness, Generosity and Selfishness at the End of Life

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Time To Leave

results.summary_short: Directed by the prolific François Ozon, “Time to Leave” stars Melvil Poupaud as a fashion photographer facing the certainty that his life will soon be over.

results.headline: A Teenager Goes From Naughty to Worse in 'Mini’s First Time'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mini's First Time

results.summary_short: “Mini’s First Time” is delectably vulgar for 20 minutes or so, almost too bad to be true, but it soon loses its cheap-thrills appeal.

results.headline: In 'Little Man,' a Jewel Thief Dons Diapers to Recover Lost Loot

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Little Man

results.summary_short: A belligerent midget jewel thief assaults groins and molests women in this infantile comedy from the Wayans brothers.

results.headline: ‘The Groomsmen’:  Growing Up Is Hard to Do, Especially When You’re 35

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Groomsmen

results.summary_short: Edward Burns paints a scathing portrait of raucous high school buddies clutching at their rock ’n’ roll glory days as they push 35.

results.headline: In '71 Fragments of a Chronology of Chance,' the Random, the Violent and the Complicit Bourgeois
results.display_title: 71 Fragments of a Chronology of Chance

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 71 Fragments of a Chronology of Chance

results.summary_short: Michael Haneke’s 1994 feature is an icy-cool study of violence both mediated and horribly real.

results.headline: In ‘Edmond,’ William H. Macy Is Desperate and Frustrated, and He Won’t Take It Anymore

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Edmond

results.summary_short: In this screen adaptation of David Mamet’s play, William H. Macy is perfectly cast as a prim Manhattan businessman who heeds his inner demons and plummets into free fall.

results.headline: ‘You, Me and Dupree’: Guess Who’s Coming to Dinner (and Staying)?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of You, Me and Dupree

results.summary_short: There are several problems with the romantic comedy “You, Me and Dupree,” not least that there is no filmmaking to speak of.

results.headline: Child Stars and a Pushy Dad in 'Two Sons of Francisco'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Two Sons of Francisco

results.summary_short: "Two Sons of Francisco" tells the real-life story of the rise of Zezé di Camargo and Luciano, a leading Brazilian country music duo.

results.headline: ‘The Color of Olives’: A Wall Runs Through It

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Color of Olives

results.summary_short: With its contemplative tone and haunting images, “The Color of Olives” may be the most peaceful documentary ever to arrive from a war zone.

results.headline: ‘Excellent Cadavers,’ an Italian Documentary, Dissects the Mafia

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Excellent Cadavers

results.summary_short: Marco Turco's meticulous and angry documentary examines the effects of Mafia power on Sicilian society and on Italian political life in the 1980’s and early 90’s.

results.headline: Laurent Cantet's 'Heading South' Shows the Ache of Blinding Lust in a Sexual Paradise Lost

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Heading South

results.summary_short: Laurent Cantet's devastating new film contemplates the darker social undercurrents beneath a seemingly benign example of sexual tourism.

results.headline: 'Once in a Lifetime' Tells the Story of a Legendary Soccer Squad
results.display_title: Once in a Lifetime: The Extraordinary Story of the New York Cosmos

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Once in a Lifetime: The Extraordinary Story of the New York Cosmos

results.summary_short: Giddy, gossipy and endearingly unslick, "Once in a Lifetime" chronicles the rise and fall of the most famous soccer team in the United States with slapdash glee.

results.headline: 'A Scanner Darkly': Keanu Reeves, Undercover and Flying High on a Paranoid Head Trip

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Scanner Darkly

results.summary_short: Identities shift and melt like shadows in Richard Linklater's animated adaptation of the 1977 novel by the science fiction visionary Philip K. Dick.

results.headline: 'Pirates of the Caribbean': Eat My Jetsam, Davy Jones
results.display_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest

results.summary_short: Although there are memorable bits and pieces, the new "Pirates of the Caribbean" is a movie with no particular interest in coherence, economy or feeling.

results.headline: 'Kill Your Idols' Presents Musicians From an Era When Downtown Meant Spit and Energy, Not Condos

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kill Your Idols

results.summary_short: S. A. Crary's music documentary examines New York's No Wave scene of the late 1970's — an offshoot of punk, the anti-New Wave.

results.headline: An Alienated Soul Wanders a European Wasteland in 'Guernsey'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Guernsey

results.summary_short: Of all the modes of modern alienation, there is none so persistent and arbitrary as finding oneself trapped in a glacially paced European art film.

results.headline: An Ancient Monster Rises Again in 'Beowulf & Grendel'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beowulf & Grendel

results.summary_short: A more accurate title of this conceptually anemic if prettily mounted take on the Scandinavian epic might be "Beowulf & the Vixen."

results.headline: 'Urbanscapes,' a Documentary on the Decaying of Neighborhoods

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Urbanscapes

results.summary_short: The documentary "Urbanscapes" plants a camera in neighborhoods gone to seed, cultivating a bittersweet portrait of American ruin.

results.headline: 'Twelve Disciples of Nelson Mandela': Life of an Anti-Apartheid Exile From a Stepson's Point of View

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Twelve Disciples of Nelson Mandela

results.summary_short: Thomas Allen Harris's film offers a fascinating glimpse of the early campaigns of the African National Congress, and the way childhood memories can obscure larger truths.

results.headline: A Motley Crew of Spirits Recruit a Boy to Be Savior in 'The Great Yokai War'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Great Yokai War

results.summary_short: Takashi Miike's excursion into extravagant and demented fantasy combines folkloric elements with images from contemporary Japanese popular culture.
